Superintendent's Message
Today‚Äôs public school student is in need of the best education that we can provide for them, especially as we witness the massive changes in our world‚Äôs workforce, but more importantly in our state. Alabama‚Äôs economy is changing and growing and our students need to be prepared to take on the jobs in a workforce that is beginning to emerge as businesses are finding their way to Alabama to set up their corporate work plants.
Our students will need more than a high school education and that is why we are committed to Empowering, Supporting and Inspiring all students. Our staff works hard to provide a nurturing environment, as well as a rigorous and challenging curriculum in order to prepare our students for the world after high school.
However, nothing is more important to us than the communication and relationship we have between the parents, community and the school.
It is an honor to serve the Anniston City Schools community as your Superintendent of Schools. We appreciate the Anniston City School System students, staff and community for creating this positive environment, which holds great promise for the future. Our work will continue to strive for academic excellence and fiscal responsibility.

In closing, I thank the entire community for continuing to work on behalf of our children.

Dr. D. Ray Hill
Superintendent of Schools

Phillip Tutor: Anniston‚Äôs students, family vacations and a Caprice Classic
Dr. D.Ray Hill, Anniston City Schools superintendent.

By Phillip Tutor, Star Columnist, ptutor@annistonstar.com

Aug 8, 2019

Dr. D. Ray Hill says he grew up in a small place about three hours south of Atlanta whose claim to fame is its title as the Peanut Capital of the World.

That‚Äôs not true.

He grew up in the back seat of a brown 1976 Caprice Classic.

Each year, Hill‚Äôs family ‚Äî dad Frank, mom Frankie, Hill and his twin sister Fay ‚Äî piled into that Caprice Classic for another adventure. The world awaited them.

Frank was a truck driver with only an eighth-grade education. Frankie made it through 11th grade. ‚ÄúBut they were smarter than what everybody figured,‚Äù Hill said Thursday morning. ‚ÄúIt was just the times that they grew up in.‚Äù

Frank wanted Ray and Fay to see what he saw ‚Äî a world much grander than their hometown of Sylvester, Ga., a world of splendor and sites and wild differences. Today, D. Ray Hill is the new superintendent of Anniston City Schools, where classes began this week.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm not going to say my parents were poor, but I can tell you that I don‚Äôt think we were rich,‚Äù Hill said, laughing. ‚ÄúBut we did things. My mother and father stretched. We got in the car, we packed sandwiches, we drove to different places, we took vacations out of state. It‚Äôs stuff like that, that‚Äôs how we expose our kids.‚Äù

Fueled by gasoline and homemade sandwiches and truck-stop visits, Frank and Frankie took the twins anywhere roads would go. The options were limitless. And, ‚ÄúI‚Äôll never forget (that Caprice Classic) because that was my car in high school,‚Äù Hill said. He laughed, again. ‚ÄúI remember having an eight-track tape player in there because my dad loved music.‚Äù

They drove to nearby places like Florida. But they also traveled to faraway sites Frank saw while driving his rig. And they never flew. Distances didn‚Äôt matter.

They drove to Mexico.

They drove to the Grand Canyon.

They drove to the Hoover Dam.

The drove to the Petrified Forest National Park.

They drove to see the redwood forests in California.

After Ray and Fay left for college, Frank and Frankie took their youngest son, Robby, to Alaska.

That‚Äôs right, they drove from Sylvester, Ga., to Alaska. And back. That‚Äôs roughly 8,000 miles, round trip.

The amount of time the Hill children spent in the back seat of that brown 1976 Caprice Classic is staggering.

‚ÄúI remember they would wake us up and say, ‚ÄòHey, hey, hey, let us show you all this ‚Äî look, look, look,‚Äô‚Äù Hill said. They bought a blanket on one of their trips; Frank and Frankie kept it for decades. Hill, then a child, bought a sombrero while in Mexico; Frank and Frankie didn‚Äôt discard it until a few years ago.

The memories ‚Äî the education of a youngster‚Äôs mind ‚Äî haven‚Äôt faded.

‚ÄúIt showed me there was a lot more out there than I was accustomed to seeing every day,‚Äù Hill said. ‚ÄúThink about it.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs access. If our kids don‚Äôt see anything but the borderlines of Anniston, what do they have?‚Äù

If you want to know anything about the man now piloting Anniston‚Äôs often-criticized schools, this is it.

Yes, he values transparency and openness and civic partnerships and empowering his principals and teachers. He isn‚Äôt a non-traditionalist. He wants more algebra and foreign-language classes. He wants to add a violin program to the elementary schools. He wants to ramp up the system‚Äôs work-training programs for students hungry for paychecks. He wants to revive the high school‚Äôs drama program.

He sees opportunities while acknowledging the roadblocks ‚Äî Anniston‚Äôs poverty, Anniston‚Äôs racial divisions, even the concerns about the system‚Äôs financial stability. If you care for Anniston and its students, pray that the city‚Äôs political headaches don‚Äôt beat him down.

But it‚Äôs experiences and opportunities, lessons that transcend and transform, that he resolutely values. He‚Äôs never far from the back seat of that Caprice Classic. He recalls that his parents ‚Äújust wanted us to be exposed‚Äù to the world, to see what‚Äôs there and what‚Äôs possible.

Years ago, as principal at North Clayton High School in Georgia, he helped arrange a trip for 35 or so students to attend Barack Obama‚Äôs presidential inauguration.

You can imagine him today climbing into an Anniston City Schools bus, filling it with students and taking them on their own adventures, adventures fueled by financial partnerships from a business community reinvested in Anniston‚Äôs schools. An education for life to go along with an education from the classroom.

‚ÄúExposure is my biggest thing for our kids,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúI have so many things I want to do.‚Äù

Phillip Tutor
